As you have probably noticed by now, they all contain "mammaries." I will ask my associate to join me TOW. . « Professor Fitz rises and walks to Howard and the mammarie completely confused.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I introduce Dr. Ludlow Branson from Columbia University. He's a mathematician of some note. Dr. Branson will now demonstrate that, in fact, Miss Russell's "mammaries" are no more prominent than any of these other fine ladies. He hands the stunned Professor Fitz a pair of calipers fr pocket.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You forgot your calipers, Doctor. Howard returns to his seat. Professor Fitz improvises:

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR FITZ
dialogues.text: Well ... gentlemen ... ah ... You'll see that in, um, mammary exhibit number one the length of the actual, cleavage, if I may, is ... (he uses the calipers) ... Five inches and quarter ... Now if we go to, um, mammary exhibit number two we will find... Professor Fitz proceeds gamely. Howard watches him. Smile Then we hear Kate:

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... don't you see how degrading this is for me?! o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cover of HOLLYWOOD EXPOSE magazine, a sleazy rag show picture of Howard with various female movie stars. The bo cover title: THE MANY LOVES OF HOWARD HUGHES. Howard is roaming, eating vanilla ice cream straight from carton as Kate follows. She holds the magazine. Furious.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Don't you see how this demeans me?!

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Since when do you care about the scandal rags?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Every time there's a picture of you with another woman it's like a slap in the face, don't you understand that?!

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: That's overstating it a bit, don't ya think? QUICK FLASHES: a series of newspaper photos of Howard wit women. Starlets and movie stars.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (brandishing magazine) Joan Crawford, Ginger Rogers, Linda Darnell, Joan Fontaine ... and now Bette Davis for God's sake!

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: They're Cracker Jack candy, honey. You know they don't: mean anything--

dialogues.speaker: RATE
dialogues.text: Oh, very nice.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You're the one who said all men are predators. It's all ain Darwin, remember? He goes into the den, she follows...

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: And am I to expect this to continue after the wedding?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What's really bothering you? Is it the women or the “ publicity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finally explodes:

dialogues.speaker: IN THE WORLD
dialogues.text: The phone on Howard's desk rings.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't you dare. He answers the phone. She is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah? -~ This isn't a good time, Odie ... What? ... (he- is now completely focused on the phone conversation) ... For Christ sake we can't make the Hercules if we can't get any aluminum. Wait... (he turns up the amplifier on his phone so he can hear better) ... Yeah, I can hear “you now ... No ~-- you tell the War Production Board thi is an éssential strategic operation and ... No... Kate steams.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: .» Look, if they're giving aluminum to Douglas and Northrop and Boeing they sure as hell can give some to Hughes Aircraft... .

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Don't set the ice cream-- He sets the messy ice cream carton on his desk. She knows will leave a ring. Intolerable.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: ... Meantime, we gotta think of something else. If we can't get any aluminum we'll have to find another way ... Christ, I don't know, find some alloy that works as well, you tell me ... Right... He continues on the phone. She stalks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard and Kate sit in the rear of a large sedan. Howard to Glenn in the front seat. A large Cuban man we will com know as JORGE drives. They are driving through the MGM lo We watch Kate's face. Clouded. Sad. Deep in thought. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: --Dammit, Odie, if we can't get any aluminum we'll use wood.

dialogues.speaker: GLENN
dialogues.text: You can't make a 200 ton plane out of wood.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Why the hell not?! The damn thing's a flying boat. What did they used to make boats out of?! Think of the Hercules like a Spanish Galleon -- a goddamn flying Spanish Galleon! They pull up to Kate's trailer. He kisses her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love you honey ... (he continues to Glenn as she climbs out of the car) ... We just gotta find the right kind of wood -- something light but strong -- with the tensile properties to work with the Duramold bonding...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MGM LOT DAY
dialogues.text: The sedan pulls away as Kate goes into her trailer...

dialogues.speaker: INT. KATE'S TRAILER DAY
dialogues.text: SPENCER TRACY is sitting comfortably rumpled and relaxed trailer. He tosses her an apple. She catches it. SPENCER TRACY ’ From my farm. If you like it I'll get you a bushel. She takes a bite of the apple. Tears come to her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER TRACY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Trouble with Mr. Hughes?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: There's too much Howard Hughes in Howard Hughes. That's the trouble. The new plane is brilliantly illuminated. It is Howard's new twin-engine reconnaissance plane. Even this incomplete state the XF-1l is dramatic. Twin rear bo flanking a needle-nosed cockpit. 65 feet long with a wing 101 feet. Extremely graceful lines, smooth surfaces and streamlined elegance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hanger is empty but for Howard. He stands at the plan working, arms thrust into the guts of the engine. A radio plays Christmas carols. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Beautiful... Howard turns, Jack Frye has just entered the hanger with GROSS, the dignified President of Lockheed. They are gazi the new plane, dazzled. Howard goes to them, cleaning his hands on a rag.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: (smiles) Don't you even take Christmas off? Gross offers his hand. Title: Robert Gross. President of Lockheed Aircraft.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (not shaking) Sorry, got grease on my hands. Nice to see you, Bob. He holds up his finger for them to be quiet. Then turns u radio so they can't be overheard.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take a look ... She's the XF-11 reconnaissance flier, spy plane really. Her top speed is 450 -- which means she can outrun anything they throw against her. After the Japs stole my H-1 design for their goddamn Zeros, I figured I needed to do 'em one better. Designed every inch of her myself.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: She's a looker.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Okay, what have you got for me? Gross carries something covered in a cloth to a drafting He pulls off the cloth, revealing a model of an airplane. Constellation. If the XF-1l1 is a radical design, the airplane model bef Howard is nothing short of revolutionary. The plane's shape is dolphin-like, elegantly dipping down nose and then sloping up to the three vertical tail wings engines. Howard almost gasps.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jiminy Cricket...

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: Seating capacity for 60. Wingspan 123 feet. Four Double Cyclone engines. Her ceiling is 25,000 feet.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (studies the model) Gross weight?

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: 86,000. Wing load to 41 pounds psi.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Less drag on the plane in thinner air, so at full mix you're looking at a top speed of -- (instantly does the math) -- around 340, giving her a range of about... Howard stops. A stunning realization.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 3,000 miles. He looks up at them. 3,000 miles. The magic number.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cross country.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Non-stop. Howard continues to look at them. 3,000 miles. The sacred number. Then he looks more closely at Gross.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You have something on your suit.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (calm) ‘ On your lapel, there's something on your lapel.

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: (looking) Where? Howard hands him a handkerchief from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Right there. Clean it off, would ya? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gross cleans a speck of lint off his lapel. Offers the handkerchief back.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Throw it away ... (Gross moves to a nearby trash can) ... No, over there. Gross tosses the handkerchief in a trash can a little fur away.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what do you call her?

dialogues.speaker: . GROSS
dialogues.text: The Constellation, but we can change that.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: No, it's pretty. Howard tucks his hands into his pockets and walks away, d thought. -

dialogues.speaker: . HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I like her ... (he glances in the trash can where Gross threw the handkerchief, disquieted) ... What kind of deal can you give me? ... (he repeats the movement and words exactly, looking into the trash can again) ... What kind of deal can you give me?

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: We'll give you the first 40 planes off the assembly line.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That'll give us about two years exclusivity with her.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: More than that. United and American don't have the imagination for a plane like this.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Two years ahead of Juan Trippe then. Howard considers. Finally turns back to them.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: GROSS
dialogues.text: 450,000 each. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: 18 million for the first forty ... Hell, TWA can't afford that. The damn airline is flat broke ... I guess I'll just have to pay for them myself ... (to Gross) ... Build ‘em, Bob, and send the bill to Noah Dietrich. Thanks. He strides out of the hanger quickly. Jack and Gross look at each other. In the blink of an eye Howard has just placed the largest commercial aircraft order in history.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard is on the phone, highly amused:

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: ... now don't get all hysterical, Noah, that's not good for you... (smiles) ... Yeah, I know, I know, I should have told you but it just slipped my mind... Kate enters. He is surprised to see her.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: I'll get back to you, thanks ... (he hangs up) ... Hey, honey, what are you doing home?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (crisply) You're not one for tears and neither am I, so best to come out with it directly: I've met someone. I've fallen in love and I'm moving out. If I could make it more gentle I would, but I can't, so there we both are.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (stunned) What? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Now let's be honest, this has all been a grand adventure but it couldn't possibly last. We're too alike you and I-

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You met someone?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Someone more appropriate to me, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What does that mean -- "appropriate"?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Someone more attuned to my needs.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Stop acting, Katie. Look at me.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I'm not acting.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I wonder if you even know anymore.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Don't be unkind.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (standing, angry) Fine -- you wanna go -- go on. Actresses are cheap in this town, darling, and I have a lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: This is beneath you--

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: No, this is exactly me! You come in here out of the blue and tell me you're leaving just like that -- and you have the nerve to expect graciousness?!

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I expect a little maturity. I expect you to face the situation like an adult who--

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: A tense beat.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't you ever talk down to me. You're a movie star. Nothing more. She looks at him. About to crumble. She will never let hi that. She turns and goes. He stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4:00 am. Howard stands at a bonfire raging in the backyar is tossing armfuls of clothes into it. Gorgeous suits and and shoes and hats go into the inferno. He finishes throwing the clothes into the fire. He watche the red flame bathing his face. Then he slowly slips off his jacket. Then shirt. Then everything.

dialogues.speaker: INT, NOAH'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Noah is fast asleep next to his WIFE. The phone by the be rings. Again. Noah opens one eye, looks at the phone.

dialogues.speaker: NOAH'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Don't answer it. Noah answers wearily:

dialogues.speaker: NOAH, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: What is it, Howard? Split-screen to Howard at home, he stands nude in his den bonfire continuing to rage in the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hey, Noah, I need you to get over to the Penney's and buy me some new clothes.

dialogues.speaker: NOAH, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Penney's isn't open.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. All right, first thing tomorrow. I want two suits off the rack, one light and one dark. Three white shirts. And three white pairs of tennis shoes. Got that? No, wait, make it Woolworths. No, no, no, Penneys ~- (he stops, suddenly suspicious) -- Noah, do you have a recorder? Are you recording this conversation?! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NOAH, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm trusting you. Listen, I need those clothes first thing, thanks -~- Wait! Wait! Wait! -- Did I say Penneys or Woolworth's?

dialogues.speaker: NOAH, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Penneys

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Better make it Sears. He hangs up. End split-screen. Noah hangs up. Sighs. Int __ MUIREIELD -- DEN __NIGHT Howard stands and watches his clothes burn. We watch his Alone. Abandoned. A lovely version of "Wrap Your Troubles in Dreams" begins

dialogues.speaker: VOCALIST
dialogues.text: "When skies are cloudy and grey, They're only grey for a day, So wrap your troubles in dreams, And dream your troubles away..." The song continues as we hear click-click-click -- taking to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Click~click-click. The click of high heels on cement. FAITH DOMERGUE walks across the empty plain of a warehous floor. The echoing warehouse appears to be vacant but for single chair with a strong light next to it. Howard sits in the chair, the bright light is focused on so she cannot really see him. He remains hidden behind th for the entire scene. We only watch her. Faith is a beautiful brunette. She tries to appear older her years, feigning a sophistication that is not natural her.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You can stop there, if you please, Miss Domergue. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops. Trapped in the glare of the light.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Would you take off your heels, please? She slips out of her shoes. Holds them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Good. Would you turn around, please? She slowly turns, trying to do it like she saw Rita Haywo in a movie once.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You know the kind of work it takes to be an actress? It takes hard work. Voice lessons and deportment lessons. And new makeup and wardrobe. It's just like going to school again. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Would you wipe off your lipstick, please? She takes a handkerchief from her purse and wipes off her red lipstick. It smears a bit.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And the rouge? Could you do something about that, please? She licks the handkerchief and attempts to clean off the Does okay. Without the makeup she is even more attractive herself anyway.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now you understand you'll be under contract to me, personally. You know what that means? You know what a contract is? It's a very serious thing. It's a legal document. She nods. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How old are you, Miss Domergue?
A beat.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Holy mother of God. "Wrap Your Troubles in Dreams" takes us to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are amidst a sea of elegant shoes effortlessly swaying a dance floor. All the shoes are formal, black. "Wrap Your Troubles in Dreams" continues es we watch the black shoes dancing. Then a pair of white tennis shoes dances past. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard is dancing with Faith. He wears his plain dark sui Sears. White shirt. White sneakers. To our surprise, perhaps, Howard is a very good dancer. They dance as we go to... A bit later. Howard and Faith sit in a corner booth with Frye and his wife, HELEN.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (happily) . ++. Car picks me up every morning at eight and off I go. I'm getting my High School diploma. Howard thinks education is important. Then after classes I'm off for elocution and grooming and fittings...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (seeing someone) Well, blow me down... Juan Trippe is approaching the table. Trippe wears nice suit. Except for a smattering of milita uniforms, Trippe and Howard are the only men in the entir not wearing tuxedos. They are worthy adversaries. Trippe arrives at the table.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) Jack, Helen, hello. JACK . Hello, Juan.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: How are you, Howard?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (shakes hands) Good, thanks. This is Miss Domergue.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Sit down. Now what the hell are you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: (pulling a chair to the booth) Meeting with Douglas on the DC-4, our new plane. She's gonna be a pip ... (to Howard) ... How's the Constellation coming? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Good. Great.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: How ‘bout letting me steal a peek?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (smiles) Don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: You know, I ought to be cross with you. You stole Ray Loewy from us.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: He's doing our interior design.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: He was doing ours. What are your colors?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Stop fishing. Trippe laughs.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Do you have buttons or zippers?

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: On the drapes for the sleeping berths.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: Zippers.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: Buttons?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Trippe considers this. Faith is rather mystified at the seriousness of all this.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: So I suppose you'll be expanding to Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: SACK
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: Your range is 3,000 miles. You'll expand from Los Angeles to Mexico. Maybe South America.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (smiles) Hey, that's a good idea, anyone got a pen?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Or across the Atlantic. Jack freezes. Trippe smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: Too far.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: New York to Newfoundland to Ireland to Paris.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: Well, Pan Am welcomes you. We're overbooked as it is. It's a great burden having to do it all. When's the Connie coming out?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Next year maybe. DC-4?

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: Next year.

dialogues.speaker: . HOWARD
dialogues.text: I look forward to her.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: And I to the Connie ... (he stands, and delivers a final knife thrust) ... I already ordered the next forty after you ... You know, I never knew you could dance. That was a rhumba, yes? He smiles and leaves the table. Howard watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Good going, boss. You just gave him our entire postwar strategy.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: He can't stop us.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He's Pan Am, Howard. He can stop anything ... (hailing passing waiter) ... Hey, fella, gimme the biggest scotch you got.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Excuse me. He stands and makes his way through the club, deep in tho He goes into the men's room... The bathroom is empty. Howard moves to a sink, taking his bar of lye soap from his pocket. “He begins washing his hands. Scrubbing his hands. He looks into the mirror as he scours his hands. His hand more quickly now. A certain urgency to the washing. And t almost violence. He does not look down. His hands are raw now. His face almost passive as he look himself in the mirror. One of his hands is bleeding now. The lye stings him. He looks down. A little bit of blood. He stares at it. Surprised. He quickly rinses off his hands and puts the soap back in pocket. Dries his hands with a towel, dabbihg away the ti of blood. Then he goes to leave the bathroom. Reaches for the door- Stops. He stares at the doorknob. HOWARD'S POV -- EXTREME CLOSEUP -- the glistening gold do His hands are clean now. He can't touch the doorknob. Wha do? He looks around.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Hello. No one else is in the bathroom. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the doorknob again. Frustrated. Then an idea. He shifts his position. Ready. He waits. He along with the music from the club. Then a man sweeps into the bathroom. Howard nips out the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COCOANUT GROVE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Howard returns to the table, all business:

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: All right, I want you to get in touch with Mr. Joyce and Mr. Berg. They're my boys in Washington. And set up a meeting with Jesse Jones, he's Secretary of Commerce, old golfing buddy—-

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Whoa, slow down--

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: We're gonna need terminals in Ireland and France and I want some tax breaks from them. If that shitheel thinks he owns the whole goddamn world he's got another think coming.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Pan Am owns Europe. But he's smart, we ought to think about Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (very firm) To hell with Mexico. No one airline should have a monopoly on flying the Atlantic. That's just not fair! Howard leans in. We have rarely seen him this intense.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He owns Pan Am. He owns Congress. He owns the Civil Aeronautics Board. But he does not own the sky. Howard notes his hand is bleeding again. Just a spot of b He presses it to his pant leg to stop the bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're in a street fight with that sonofabitch and I am not going to lose. I been fighting high hat, Ivy League pricks like him my whole life. And listen, fire Ray Loewy. He's spying for Trippe. That shitheel knew all about the buttons. Spies in my midst. 'Scuse me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Howard is up and gone, heading toward the bathroom ag As we hear an amplified voice:

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: +--+ pleased to bring you The Wonder Of Modern Aviation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like a trade show. With one vendor. An EMCEE stands before a microphone on a stage at one end hanger. A red velvet curtain emblazoned with "Hughes Airc hangs across the stage, concealing something. A gaggle of reporters wait. As does the all~important delegation from the Air Corps. men in uniform. Each is with a beautiful, younger woman. These seven men will decide whether or not to fund the pr

dialogues.speaker: . EMCEE
dialogues.text: ++. Not just a plane, ladies ‘and gentlemen, a vast leap forward in aeronautic technology. But it's more than that. It's our humble gesture to the war effort, our chance to help out those brave men in uniform... The Emcee continues to ballyhoo as we find Howard in a co the hanger, standing with Johnny Meyer. Howard's eyes never leave the delegation from the Air Cor he pulls a rumpled tie from his pocket and puts it on:

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: ++. and every bill comes to me. They don't pay for anything. Those men decide whether or not to fund the plane, so I need them real happy, do what it takes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What about the girls?

dialogues.speaker: JOHRNNY
dialogues.text: Let's put it this way ... I don't think the gentlemen from the Air Corps will have any trouble scoring tonight. The Emcee continues: (CONT INTEND)

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE
dialogues.text: ++. And now let me introduce you to the creator of this magnificent airplane. You know him as an aviator, an industrialist, an American hero. We here at Hughes Aircraft just know him as a patriot. Ladies and gentlemen ... Howard Hughes. The crowd applauds. Howard joins the Emcee on the stage. looks out over the sea of faces. Doesn't know quite what Settles for:

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Well, let's see her. Gorgeous starlets emerge and slowly pull back the red cur reveal... The Hercules. History will come to know it as The Spruce Goose. A huge silver model of the gigantic flying boat slowly re a glowing Art Deco sign flashing "The Hercules" behind it from the crowd. Flashbulbs. But Howard only has eyes for Corps delegation. dialogues.text: Jesus, Ava-~

dialogues.text: How long can they keep us grounded?

dialogues.speaker: JACK

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Honey, listen to me--

dialogues.text: What do you wanna hear?! You wanna hear me screwing Mickey Rooney -- that do it for you, Howard?! You wanna hear me screwing Sinatra?! You goddamn faggot -- screw them yourself if you're so interested--!

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I'm concerned about you, baby, I just wanna make sure you're okay-- She goes to a window, tears open the drapes--

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: And who's in that car? That goddamn car is with me twenty-four hours a day--

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: It's there for your protection!

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: The only one I need protected from is you, you sick bastard! ~- You don't own me, Howard -- I'm not one of your teenage whores and I'm not some damn airplane--!

dialogues.text: (implores) Look, I'm sorry, Ava, listen to me, I'll have them take all the bugs out. You just have to understand that ... that I need to know where you are.

dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Because I worry about you.

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: Bullshit ... (she stops) ... What do you mean all the bugs? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: AVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you mean all the bugs?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: There's more.

dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Maybe ... twelve. And on the telephones. She looks at him. Shocked and saddened in equal measure.

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: Oh Christ, Howard, on the telephone ... You listen to my phone calls?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Oh no, honey ... I just read the transcripts. She looks at him. Then very carefully picks up a large, marble ashtray. She flings it at his head, he tries to duck but the ashtr slams into his forehead. Blood.

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: Get out of here ... You sad ... pathetic ... freak. Howard goes.

dialogues.text: Howard walks to his car, mumbling to himself, dabbing at blood on his head with a handkerchief. Jorge, his Cuban enforcer, is waiting. Jorge holds a phon extends from inside the car.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD

Brewster walks through the apartment, meets Howard being escorted in by a MAID. Howard wears his dark suit. White No tie. White sneakers. Howard is making a superhuman effort to appear "normal."

dialogues.text: Howard, hello. He strides up, offering his hand. Howard forces himself t Brewster's hand and shake firmly.

dialogues.speaker: . HOWARD

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Love it, thanks. Brewster is disappointed. Howard forces himself to dig in maid pours water into their glasses. Howard has the glass Brewster smudged with his thumb print before.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Thanks. Brewster is disappointed that his childish game of psycho warfare is failing so miserably.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: All right, let's talk turkey ... My investigators have turned up a lot of dirt. It could be really embarrassing if this stuff got out. I'd like to save you that embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: That's very kind of you, Owen.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: My Committee has the power to hold public hearings. I'd like to spare you that.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Agree to support my C.A.B. bill and Z won't hold public hearings.

dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD

dialogues.text: We didn't. We flew.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD

His mental loop is broken when the red light above the sc room door begins to flash. Someone is outside. He goes to the door. He talks through the door, waging a terrible battle to sound sane.

dialogues.text: Unlock this door immediately.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Did you say something?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (tormented) I can't. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: KATE

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (softly) Howard ... please let me see you.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I haven't shaved.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I don't care. Let me in.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I can hear you ... I could always hear you. Even in the cockpit, with the engines...

dialogues.speaker: KATE

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Howard, I came to thank you ... I found out what you did for Spence and me. Buying those awful pictures.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You love him.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: He's everything I have.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I'm glad for you, Kate ... Katie. Howard proceeds with great difficulty:

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go away now. Would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (tears) Howard...

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Go away, just for now, I'll see you soon. We'll go flying.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Please take me flying again ... I can take the wheel ... Howard? ... Are you there? A long beat and then she turns and walks down the long co devastated. He hears her footsteps echoing away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On her half of the split-screen we see her walking away a Howard sinks to the floor. He holds his knees and rocks l feral child. Inarticulate moans coming from deep within h She disappears around a corner, the hallway is empty. How alone. End Split-screen. And Howard's journey into hell begins. He never leaves the screening room. For months.

dialogues.text: ...it doesn't take a genius to read a blueprint. Note the hydraulics for the right aileron shown on print number 2,187-B, it is out of alignment by almost an eighth of an inch. This lack of attention to detail is unacceptable... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: We see engine parts scattered about like corpses after a We see brown paper bags and newspapers are stacked messil around. We see grainy surveillance photos of Ava out on d with other men... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ++. You must understand this is the most important thing in my life. When the milk bottles are delivered to the screening room, the employee with the bottles must wear a white shirt and no jacket. His cuffs must be completely buttoned and he must not wear a watch or jewelry or cologne of any kind. He must use no less than fifty Kleenex brand tissues to form a paddle. HOWARD’ (V.O.) © (CONT'D) -.-- I would like to remind the TWA board of directors that I own 78 percent of the airline, and the Finance Committee's recommendation to raise 20 million dollars in capitalization through the sale of common stock is contrary to my intentions at this time... We see reels of movie film, some unspooled, the film stre around the room like celluloid tendons. We see his clothe discarded. The "milk bottle" memo is heard again as the others conti

dialogues.text: ... The employee with the milk bottles must press the button seven times exactly. When he has heard me repeat the words "Come in with the milk" ten times, with no variation, "Come in with the milk", ten times, he must then use his left hand to open the door and enter. We return to the ants, slowly creeping across the plate o cookies. Tenacious. Omnivorous. Unstoppable. As all the memos, and hundreds more, now join together fo versions of the final, all-important instruction: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: -.. If there is any variation of these instructions, even to the smallest degree, the entire process must be repeated from the beginning ... repeated from the beginning ... repeated from the beginning.. And we finally see Howard. He stands, naked. He stands in front of the screen. Silent images from HELL ANGELS are being projected. A dogfight scene. The planes and-soar over his naked body. The only sane order in this hellish place seems to be a n of empty milk bottles against one wall. : Howard slowly backs away from the screen. His whole psych concentrating on a series of sounds ... syllables ... let ... fighting to find order in chaos. It is painfully emot Every correct letter is a huge victory, every incorrect l is a crushing defeat. :

dialogues.text: He slowly walks to the pristine row of empty milk bottles

dialogues.speaker: Q...U... A...
dialogues.text: He picks one up. Pees in it.

dialogues.speaker: -R...A--E--A...N...

dialogues.speaker: Q...U... E...R..-
dialogues.text: He sets the milk bottle down. We realize there is an endl line of the milk bottles on this side of the room. All fi with urine. Precisely ordered. He looks at them. Trying not to weep. Concentrating inten

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -A...R...N...7... Bee. Ewe. De. Nee. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then a red light reflects off the milk bottles. The door He goes to the door, talks through it.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello ... ? Split-screen to: A rather mystified Juan Trippe outside the screening room A chair has been placed in the hallway. Noah waits down t hall.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: Howard, it's Juan.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Oh, Juan, right, right. We had an appointment, I remember that -- Listen I got a hell of a cold here. Why don't you sit down out there? Don't wanna get you sick. Never forgive myself if I got you sick. You don't wanna get sick-- Howard clamps a hand over his mouth, fighting with himsel Outside, Trippe sits.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: Okay, Howard, I'm sitting ... (he begins pulling documents from his briefcase) ... Now, I've brought all our accountings. Pan Am is trading at 13.66 a share. TWA is trading at 4.24. If we--

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Come on, come on, come on, come on -- we both know I'm not going to sell TWA. You couldn't afford her anyway. Our domestic routes alone are worth more than twice Pan Am.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: Considering our stock is valued at three times yours, I find that a dubious claim, Howard. Howard forces himself to concentrate, eyes shut.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I mean you have no domestic routes. You get TWA and you span the globe -- I'm not gonna sell, and you know I'm not going to sell -- Here's the point: Owen Brewster works for you. Outside, Trippe prepares his pipe. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: I didn't elect Senator Brewster. We can thank the vote of Maine for that.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: If I appear at his hearings, it might get nasty for a} of us.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: I think considerably more for you. While the good peo; of America lost sons at Anzio, you produced a dirty movie and built airplanes that don't fly. nutside, Trippe lights his pipe.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Now that's just not fair. The XF-11 flew quite well f an hour and forty five minutes. I wish you’d been up there with me. It was very exciting. oward smiles gleefully. Take that, you sonofabitch. Then otices a wisp of smoke from Trippe's pipe coming under th oor. It is noxious, lethal. Howard backs away from. the d

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: Be that as it may, you still have to answer for the Spruce Goose. .

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (calling from across the room) It's called the Hercules -~ and it'll fly goddammit!

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: I hope it does. America should know what its $13 milli bought.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (calling from across the room) I won't sell TWA! utside, Howard's distress is all too apparent to Trippe.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: I know... e leans back, the cat with the canary. Howard cautiously ‘ack to the door as Trippe speaks:

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm going to get it anyway. You're going to default on your loan from Equitable when Senator Brewster destroys your reputation and you can't raise additional capital for the airline. The hearings will also show Hughes Aircraft to be mismanaged and incompetent. It will go bankrupt. But you won't be insolvent. You'll still have Toolco ... Perhaps you'll go back to Houston and rebuild your empire. I rather hope you do. By that time Pan Am will have bought TWA and painted all those magnificent Connies blue and white. So, when you do return, it will be on a Pan Am plane. Howard stands right at the door.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You seem to have me in a corner, buddy. Not a position in which I'm very comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: I think you'll be less comfortable at Senator Brewster's hearings. Very public, Howard. Lots of cameras and newsmen. I understand you're not particularly comfortable in crowds. Trippe's droll understatement makes Howard smile.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Perhaps we should spare you that.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Thanks for your concern. I find that very moving ... It's been a real pleasure, Juan. Noah will take you back to the airport. Fly safe. Outside, Trippe stands.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Howard. Take care of that cold.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I certainly will. Bye bye. He thrusts his ear to the door, listening. Making sure Tr gone. He hears Trippe and Noah moving away. End split-screen. Howard leans against the door, panting. The exertion of t with Trippe has absolutely éxhausted him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he again moves to the HELL'S ANGELS footage on the s The planes twists and fly over his naked body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noah and Juan Trippe head down the corridor to the elevat look approaching sympathy on Trippe's face.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPE
dialogues.text: (quietly) If you let him appear at the hearings the whole world will see what he's become ... People should remember him as he was. Noah does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll get a subpoena in three days to appear in Washington. Noah does not respond, but the pain to him of Howard's ma is clear in his eyes. They move away and we remain in the hallway-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME LAPSE. Days and nights pass. Employees appear and disappear. Finally... iT. 7000 ROMAINE -- CORRIDOR NIGHT The door to the screening room opens slightly. Howard pee A few employees move about in the corridor. He carefully steps from the screening room, standing in t doorway, not quite ready to leave his sanctuary. He has p some clothes. A FEMALE SECRETARY stops when she sees Howard. She is abs amazed, no one has actually seen Howard for months. She is a bit frightened at his appearance.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Mr. Hughes...?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (a whisper) I don't have any shoes. Can you get me some shoes?

dialogues.speaker: NT. MUIRFIELD. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Howard sits on the floor in his den, wearing only an old bathrobe. He is unshaven, his eyes red with exhaustion an tears. He aimlessly sorts through a mountain of legal documents, to prepare himself for his upcoming appearance in Washing The doorbell rings. He pulls himself up and slowly moves the silent house. He is fragile, moving unsteadily. He is made of straw, as if a wisp if air could blow him way. He looks through the peephole and then pulls a wad of Kle from a waiting box. He uses the Kleenex to open the front It is Ava. She looks at him, stunned. Recovers quickly.

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: How nice of you to dress for me ... Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You can come in. He nervously looks past her as she enters. He shuts the d behind her and locks it.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming.

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: I thought long and hard about it, I can tell you ... (she pulls off her fur wrap, smiles) ... But, hell, no one's bugged me for months now, guess I was feeling lonely ... (offers him her wrap) ... Wanna hang this up? He looks at her wrap. Doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: AVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hang this up for me, Howard ... Go on, take it. He quickly grabs a new wad of Kleenex and uses it to take stole and quickly hang it up in a hall closet.

dialogues.speaker: AVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now let's get a drink...

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: No, wait, wait, wait -- you can't move -- you're safe here. You're in the germ free zone now, you understand? Ava glances down, notes this area of the entry hall is ma off by a square of black electrical tape on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: T'll take my chances. She steps over the tape and moves into the house.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: No, no, honey, please... Howard follows nervously as she strides through the airle darkened house to the living room. She notes all the wind taped shut with black electrical tape. Even more, she cannot help noticing the mountains of Klee discarded everywhere on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: Love what you've done with the place ... (she pours herself a drink) ... Kleenex carpet's a cute idea. Now let me look at you. She switches on a table lamp. He stands before her. Holdi robe closed tightly.

dialogues.speaker: AVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drop the robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He removes the robe. He stands naked. She gazes over hin.

dialogues.speaker: AVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, you need to eat for one ... and a shower might be in order ... (her eyes play over him a bit more, mischievous) ... Well, I always said they don't call it Hughes Tool for nothing. He actually smiles.

dialogues.speaker: AVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's my boy. Get the robe, come on... He picks up the robe. Looks at it. He seems to have forgo how to put it on. Ava goes to him and gently helps him--

dialogues.speaker: AVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put your arm through the hole -- right, good, all the way through -- okay, now the other... She helps him put the robe on and then takes his hand and him toward the stairs... INT. UTRFIELD -— T) THROOM. NIGHT He stands. She shaves him.

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: When do you go to Washington?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: A week. No, just under a week. I don’t know the date today. But I have to be ... I have to be...

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: All right, take it easy. A silent beat as she shaves him. His eyes are drawn to th the running water, the soap. HOWARD'S POV ~- EXTREME CLOSEUP -- the gleaming white por sink, the tap water rinsing off the shining razor, the ti beard hairs swirling down the drain--

dialogues.speaker: AVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's nothing there, Howard. A silent pause as she shaves him.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I see things.

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: I know, baby. Rinse your face off now. She steps aside. He faces the sink. Slowly reaches forwar Stops.

dialogues.speaker: AVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put your hands in the water and wash off the soap. I'm right here. I'm not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Does it look clean to you?

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: Nothing's clean, Howard. But we do our best, right? He slowly reaches forward and puts his hands into the run water. He carefully washes the soap off his face. A trium looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: AVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Great. Now I want you in the shower.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Don't go anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: Hell, I'd soap you up myself but I know how frisky you get. He smiles and steps toward the shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard stands unsteadily before a mirror, as presentable can make him. Clean, hair slicked down, nails cut, new su

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I look all right...

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: You look great.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Will you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: You're too crazy for me. She looks at him tenderly in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: AVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I gotta go, baby.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Okay ... Thanks. She kisses him gently.

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: You'd do it for me. He nods. She goes. He stands for a moment, looking at him the mirror. Cosmetically at least, he has improved. But h still reflect the chaos inside him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SENATE CAUCUS ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: Barely controlled hysteria. The Senate Caucus Room is jammed. 1,500 spectators and re are packed into a chamber built to handle 600. Hundreds m crowd the hallway outside. Title: August 6, 1947. Brewster Senate Hearings. Day One. The witness table holds a cluster of microphones from sev radio stations. Six newsreel cameras purr alongside an am new invention: a television camera. This was the first congressional hearing in history to be televised live. Across from the witness table, Owen Brewster sits at a lo with the rest of his committee. Then a sound, growing from outside the chamber, a buildin rumble of excited voices. Brewster glances up from his no see Howard walking into the chamber with Noah. Howard wea crisp new grey suit. The photographers snap photos, a barrage of flashbulbs, a excited clamor from the ‘spectators. Howard ignores the press and spectators and goes to the w table. Sits. Noah sits next to him, begins unloading two briefcases full of documents. Then blinding lights suddenly snap on, focused on Howard. are the lights to assist the new TV camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are so powerful that many of the reporters put sunglasses. It is a surreal image as the reporters don th sunglasses and the cold eye of the TV camera gazes at How Howard looks almost robotic, flattened, unfocused. Brewster knows he is going to slaughter him. He bangs a g for order.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: The committee will come to order. Mr. Hughes, will you raise your right hand and be sworn? Howard stands, raises his right hand. Another barrage of flashbulbs. Howard's pupil's dilate and undilate furiousl the strobe-like flashes.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you solemnly swear that in the matter now pending before this committee, you will tell the trzth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you God?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I do- He sits.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Mr. Hughes, it is the intention of this committee--

dialogues.speaker: NOAH
dialogues.text: Mr. Hughes has a statement.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Very well. Mr. Hughes, you may proceed. Noah holds out a piece of paper to Howard. Howard glances Glances away. He says nothing. An awkward beat.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Hughes? You may proceed... Noah is getting nervous. He offers the statement to Howar again. Howard won't take it. Then Howard looks off to the who stare back at him. At the cruel eye of the TV camera. Howard looks back to Brewster. And his eyes begin to flicker with something we've seen b Howard ignores the prepared statement.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You know, I'm gonna attempt to be, um, honest here... A beat. Noah is terrified of what Howard is going to say. focuses, glaring at Brewster.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Senator Brewster, if you hadn't gone too far overboard, I might have been willing to take a certain shellacking in this publicity spree of yours. I might have been willing to sit back and take a certain amount of abuse simply because I am only a private citizen while you are a Senator with all sorts of powers -- But I think this goddamn circus has gone on long enough-- Brewster bangs his gavel--

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: That's quite sufficient, Mr. Hughes--

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (angry) . . You have called me a liar, sir. In the press. You have called me a liar and a thief and a war profiteer--

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: (banging gavel) The witness will restrain his comments and-- Howard stands, a stunningly simple act that silences Brew and rivets the entire room. He leans forward on the table speaking with clipped, barely controlled anger:

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Why not tell truth for once, Senator? Why not tell that this investigation was really born on the day that TWA first decided to fly to Europe? On the day when TWA first invaded Juan Trippe's territory. On the day when TWA first challenged the generally accepted theory that only Juan Trippe's great Pan American Airways had the sacred right to fly the Atlantic! The bombshell explodes. The spectators love seeing Howard America's Aviation Hero, defending himself. The photograp flash pictures. Brewster bangs his gavel to no avail. Howard continues to stand. We sweep across the approving spectators and then sweep b the next day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard is sitting, leaning an elbow on the table, holding amplifier earpiece to his ear to hear Brewster. focused. Completely (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Title: Day Two.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - and on February 12th of this year, in your suite at the Mayflower Hotel, did you or did you not tell me that if I would sell TWA to Pan Am this investigation would be called off?

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: (shrill) I did not.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: How long have you known Juan Trippe?

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: I have known Mr. Trippe for several years. But-- Noah slides Howard a piece of paper, he doesn't need to l it.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Is it not true, Senator Brewster, that Juan Trippe donated 20,000 dollars to your last campaign and--?

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: I have a personal friendship with Mr. Trippe that is -- um -- divorced from my duties as a Senator. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Is it not true that you accept free tickets from Pan Am so you can circle the globe in support of your C.A.B. bill?

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: It is not.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Who wrote that bill, Senator?

dialogues.speaker: . BREWSTER
dialogues.text: I don't understand the purpose of--

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Who actually wrote the C.A.B. bill? The actual words in the bill. Did you write them, Senator?

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Mr. Hughes, this is--

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I have it here, maybe that will refresh your memory ... (Noah hands him a copy of the thick bill) ... Here we go. Bill S. 987 to amend the Civil Aeronautics Act. You introduced this bill into the Senate. Lotta words. You write all of them? Brewster sputters.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You write any of them?

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Now see here, Mr. Hughes--

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: This entire bill was written by Pan Am executives and designed to give that airline a monopoly on international travel! And you've been flogging this bill on their behalf all around the world, have you not?!

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: My duties take me to--

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What in hell does a Senator from Maine need to visit Peru for?

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: (flustered) I was -- ah -- seeking outlets for our trade goods.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: They buy a lot of lobsters down there, do they?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: How many times have you been to Mr. Trippe's office in New York in the last three months? ... (Brewster stops cold) ... Would you like me to tell you, Senator?

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: (exploding) This has gone on long enough -- Juan Trippe is a great American and his airline has advanced the cause of commercial aviation in this country for decades! Juan Trippe is a patriot! Juan Trippe isn't a man interested in making money! Howard lets Brewster's absurd final words echo around the chamber. He leans back, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sure his stockholders will be happy to hear that. Chuckles from the spectators. We sweep over the spectators and sweep back to the next d Howard is leaning back, holding the amplifier earpiece to ear. Noah is exhausted, the days of grueling testimony ta toll. Howard is completely on top of his game. The chamber is silent, the reporters and spectators strai catch every word. This is really it. Title: Day Three.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Did you receive 43 million dollars to manufacture 100 XF- 11 spy planes for the United States Air Force?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I did. BREWSTER . How many functional planes were delivered to the United States Air Force?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: None. . “ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Would you lean a little closer to the microphones, sir?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (leaning in) None.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Did you receive 13 million dollars from the United States Air Force to manufacture a protctype flying boat, know as The Hercules?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Did you deliver that plane?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I did not.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: So, by your admission in this chamber you received 56 million dollars from the United States government for planes that you did not deliver.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: That is correct. Brewster thinks he has him. But can't help pushing the da a bit.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Well, excuse me for asking, Mr. Hughes, but where did all that money go?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: It went into the planes. And a lot more.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: (leans back, satisfied) More? ... Do tell, Mr. Hughes, what other larcenies have you committed?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I mean my money, sir. Brewster is immediately alarmed, realizes he has stumbled He has given Howard the opening he has been waiting for.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Mr. Hughes, your personal finances are not the--

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER SENATOR
dialogues.text: Brewster glances at the other Senators. They stare back a coldly. Brewster sees the waiting press and spectators.

dialogues.speaker: BREWSTER
dialogues.text: Proceed, Mr. Hughes.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (very quietly) You see the thing is I care very much about aviation. It's been the great joy of my life. So I put my own money into these planes ... I've lost millions, Mr. Chairman. And I'll go on losing millions. It's just what I do. The chamber is silent. Hanging on every word.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And if I lost a lot of the government's money during the war, I hope folks will put that in perspective ... More than 60 other airplanes ordered from such firms as Boeing and Lockheed and Douglas and Northrop never saw action either. In all, more than 800 million dollars was spent during the war on planes that never flew. More than 6 billion on other weapons that were never delivered. A beat. The coup de grace:

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And yet Hughes Aircraft ~- with her 56 million -- is the only firm under investigation here today. A tremor through the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can't help but think that has a little more to do with TWA than with planes that didn't fly. Brewster slumps.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have only one more thing to say to this committee, and that's about the Hercules ... Now, I'm supposed to be many things which are not complimentary. I am supposed to be capricious. I have been called @ playboy. I have even been called an eccentric. But I do not believe I have the reputation of being a liar ... I put the sweat of my life into this thing. My reputation is wrapped up an it. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So believe me when I say that if the Hercules fails to fly, I will leave the country and I will not return. And I mean it. Then Howard slowly stands. (CONTINITED)
